title: Serious issues within the league community (and also my permaban LOL)
body:
Just got permabanned today for making a couple of jokes. I took up the teemo "persona" and tilted the other team in all chat. The popup said my comms were "extremely inflammatory and offensive", while all i did was say "I have more kills than u LMAO" in various manners. I called the lux trash once, but that was due to her calling me a %%%%%%, so I think it's fair to let that one pass by (if that was the ONE reason than got me the ban). Couple of smileys here and there and i told the vei that he'll stay iron, since he can't land his q on a sedentary target at point black distance (not really inflammatory as much the truth). There was only one game, and here's the logs:

Moving on to a more general note, even though I wasn't even toxic, I think this entire concept of what toxicity is and where it stems from is pretty important. It's something most people don't address because it gives them  a sense of power when they report someone postgame and see the instant feedback report (trust me, i know). The fact of the matter is, toxicity is ever-present in competitive environments. Hell, even my ban notification says that the vast majority agree the game is intense and competitive.  You can't really get rid of it without getting rid of the competitive feel of the game that attracts so many players. There's also the the fact that the majority of toxicity in the game arises from other players trolling. When one person runs it down mid or intentionally messes up in a game, that effects of it are unavoidable. On the other hand, to deal with "toxicity" there are measures, such as the mute button, making the effects of it minute compared to trolls. Yet the ones who get banned are the ones who react to the trolling, not the root of the problem itself, because the trolls are "just having a bad game". I've been playing league, first casually, for a long time, and in my knowledge, riot has made ZERO EFFORTS to combat the issue of trolling, while they've done everything from banning T1 to implementing an honor system for the sake of toxicity. The only concept that barely worked was Tribunal, and it worked because the ones judging you were peers, other players, who didn't hold any prejudice against you. Don't know why they took that out. Every time I reported someone for actually trolling, I've gotten no feedback reports, while I've gotten plenty for reporting someone saying something as shallow as "you're stupid". It's to the point where I don't report people for being toxic anymore, **because I acknowledge that what caused that toxicity wasn't them as a player, but rather the game itself, meaning they don't deserve punishment.**

You can look at other competitive games that have lasted years, just like league, that aren't dying (unlike league lmao, tho the kda thing was pretty snazzy imo), and you'll see that the companies those games were created by don't create an artificial snowflake environment for their players. **They understand that a significant part of a competition is to not crack under pressure or give in to insults, so they give the players that responsibility. **CS:GO is a great example of this, as the game has no bans based on toxicity, but rather if u just intentionally suck at the game or troll. Valve understands toxicity, at most, warrants a mute and nothing else.

TL;DR
Got banned for legitimately no reason, check chat logs, I explain why toxicity is in the essence of competition and therefore league, so hard to get rid of and ban for (hard to summarize).

Quite frankly, I don't even care anymore if my account doesn't get unbanned. I'm happy that riot themselves decided to end my league career here, as I was about to reach the end of the line anyway. Not here to play in a make-believe environment of happiness and positivity lol I like the real world better. I will miss the old days of league though.

Regards,
TheChosenBurrito

And that's what they gave you; they gave you an honest opinion and explained how things factually work, to which you responded with personal insults and unprofessional behaviour.

And just to address some of your points real quick:

> I explain why toxicity is in the essence of competition

No, it isn't. You don't see professional tennis players, for example, screaming insults at the top of their lungs or provoking their opponent during a match. You also don't see them saying "haha you suck" at the end of it. They shake hands and respect each other. 

-----

> On the other hand, to deal with "toxicity" there are measures, such as the mute button

If you have to mute someone, the damage has already been done. It's like blaming someone who got shot for not wearing a bulletproof vest 24/7. Just because there's a way to shield yourself when it's needed, doesn't mean it should be perceieved as "Oh, I can flame, they can just mute me if they don't like it." 

-----

> Yet the ones who get banned are the ones who react to the trolling, not the root of the problem itself
 riot has made ZERO EFFORTS to combat the issue of trolling, while they've done everything from banning T1 to implementing an honor system for the sake of toxicity

-----

You can react to trolling, but you cannot go out of your boundaries. People "reacting" to it usually means them flaming a troll, basically, and breaking the rules themselves in the process. On top of that, gameplay related offences are harder to monitor and require more information than chat related ones. Everything is crystal clear in one's chat log(s), whereas gameplay analysis takes more things into consideration. 

-----

> The only concept that barely worked was Tribunal, and it worked because the ones judging you were peers, other players, who didn't hold any prejudice against you

It didn't work. That's why it got removed in the first place. It took an extremely long time to punish a player, making speed one of its major issues. In order for a player to feel the impact of their punishment, said punishment has to be handed out **quickly **(and that's exactly what the Instant Feedback system is capable of doing). Otherwise, the effect of a system is highly neglected and disregarded. Taking up to a month to punish someone is simply unacceptable, which is why Riot now have a much better and faster system in charge of dealing with toxic behaviour.

Also, how can an automated system be prejudiced?

-----

> Every time I reported someone for actually trolling, I've gotten no feedback reports

They don't always pop up. That's intentional, so as to reduce spam.

-----

>  just like league, that aren't dying (unlike league lmao

League isn't dying. It's just a common fallacious argument people like to throw around to suit their own narrative.
